verses.text: Since they hated knowledge and did not choose to fear the LORD,
since they would not accept my advice and spurned my rebuke,

rsbNotes.title: Pr 1:29
rsbNotes.text: 1:29 knowledge. This word is a synonym for wisdom, and is explained here by the phrase parallel with it, “the fear of the Lord.” Wisdom comes from above (James 3:17), as God’s gift in redemptive revelation. This is true even when it must be desired and strived for (2:4–6; Heb. 5:7, 8; James 1:5).

verses.text: they will eat the fruit of their ways and be filled with the fruit of their schemes.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 1:31
rsbNotes.text: 1:31 fruit. The relationship between deed and outcome is observable in natural cause and effect. Here the image is not one of pleasure after a full meal, but disgust at being glutted.

verses.text: For the waywardness of the simple will kill them, and the complacency of fools will destroy them;

rsbNotes.title: Pr 1:32
rsbNotes.text:
1:32 turning away. Indifference or willful neglect.

complacency of fools. The ignorant self-satisfaction of the willfully unteachable, who see no need to learn anything from anyone.

verses.text: but whoever listens to me will live in safety and be at ease, without fear of harm."

rsbNotes.title: Pr 1:33
rsbNotes.text: 1:33 This verse stands in direct contrast with v. 32. Wisdom brings life and security. To reject wisdom is to reject all that promotes life.
